title: Man who battered dementia sufferer with hammer let out of psychiatric unit months later
text:
The brutal attack on John Clowes was like something from a ‘horror film’ (Picture: BPM Media)

The family of a retired police officer who was bludgeoned with a hammer are appalled his assailant is now allowed on the streets for two hours a week.

Granddad John Clowes was repeatedly hit over the head as he lay in bed at his sheltered housing complex in Clayton, Newcastle-under-Lyme, Staffordshire.

Simba Muguti was found not guilty of attempted murder by reason of insanity after a jury received instructions from a judge.

Mr Clowes’ loved ones were reassured his 28-year-old tormentor would be detained indefinitely for psychiatric treatment and would never be able to harm anyone else.

But just a year on from the traumatic ordeal, his family were told Muguti has been granted escorted leave with two members of staff.

When Mr Clowes, 77, who has dementia, was told the news by his wife, it all came flooding back, leaving him in fear of his attacker coming after him again.

The family are terrified of what can happen and think it is too soon to release him (Picture: BPM Media)

His devastated granddaughter Donna Flynn, 36, from Clayton, is worried about what could happen, as it took six police officers to detain Muguti, who was ‘Tasered twice in the heart’.

She added: ‘Never did we think he’d be allowed back into the community less than a year after the attack.’

Ms Flynn says he had been released from Harplands Hospital to self medicate because staff thought it was safe – six weeks before attacking Mr Clowes.

She added: ‘It’s a miraculous recovery just five-and-a-half months since the trial where two of the country’s top doctors said he was insane and a danger to the public.

‘We feel completely and utterly let down by the justice system. How can somebody like that be released back into the public for two hours a week?’

However Muguti, from Clayton, wont be allowed to visit the Stoke-on-Trent area.

The retired police officer is now living in fear (Picture: BPM Media)

Ms Flynn added: ‘My dad was a serving police officer and this is how he’s being repaid.

‘We wanted him to go to jail but now when he does leave hospital he won’t even have a criminal record.’

The family received a letter from the Ministry of Justice on September 9 informing them of the decision.

It came just 11 months after Muguti carried out the attack on October 14 last year.

Stafford Crown Court heard how Mr Clowes’ wife Jennifer Clowes, 74, was woken at 3.40am and saw a man carrying a hammer.

She ran into a room to take cover and closed a door before armed police arrived and found Muguti standing in darkness in a room at the end of a corridor.

Once he was finally handcuffed officers found Mr Clowes in his bed covered in blood with a severed left ear, permanent scars, head injuries and a black eye.

Ms Flynn says someone could have died if her 13-year-old daughter who was in the house hadn’t rang 999.

She added: ‘I’m always convinced that he is going to come back. He lived five minutes away from my nana and granddad and he targeted a housing complex which he knew would be full of vulnerable people.

‘My two children sleep with hammers under their beds because they’re so scared.’

Mrs Clowes, who has since moved house with her husband, says the night of the attack was like a ‘horror film’.

She said: ‘I’m absolutely fuming. It’s only five and half months since the trial and I feel as if we’ve been left down.

Their neighbour Barbara Morris, 58, who was also targeted by the same man, is ‘gutted’ by the latest news.

She said: ‘Even though it is just two hours a week I wouldn’t feel comfortable walking around the streets with him there.

‘He was so strong when he was banging the hammer on our door and I am worried that he will be on the streets with just two staff members.

‘At the trial they said he could be dismissed from attending the proceedings because they believed if he heard what had happened it would cause him to react, so how can somebody who was like that five months ago now be allowed in public?’

description: The man who attacked a retired police officer with a hammer in Clayton, Newcastle-under-Lyme, Staffordshire, is now allowed out of hospital.
